Published Date: 2016-01-01 18:27:24
Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Lassa fever - Nigeria: (KN)
Archive Number: 20160101.3905902

LASSA FEVER - NIGERIA: (KANO)
*****************************
A ProMED-mail post
http://www.promedmail.org
ProMED-mail is a program of the
International Society for Infectious Diseases
http://www.isid.org

Date: Thu 31 Dec 2015
From: Dr. Muktar A. Gadanya <gadanya@gmail.com> [edited]


The case counts for local government areas in Kano state as of 29 Dec 2015 are:
Garun 2 confirmed, 4 probable, 1 suspected, deaths 1
Bebeji 1 suspected
Bunkuri 1 suspected
Fagge 1 suspected
Tarauni 1 suspected

--
Dr. Muktar A. Gadanya, MBBS, MSc (London), DLSHTM, MWACP, FMCPH, MFR
Consultant Public Health Physician/Senior Lecturer
Department of Community Medicine
Aminu Kano Teaching Hospital, Bayero University
Kano
Nigeria
<gadanya@gmail.com>

[This communication provides an update and additional probable and suspected Lassa fever cases in Kano state, along with the local government area in which they occurred. ProMED thanks Dr. Gadanya for sending in this report.

The latest Nigeria Centre for Disease Control, Nigeria Federal Ministry of Health Bulletin No. 5 (44) issued on 6 Nov 2015 indicated that Lassa fever cases were reported in 12 states in Nigeria in 2015 (see ProMED-mail archive no. 20151125.3819446). Kano was not among the states listed, so the cases that ProMED posted on 24 Dec 2015 may be the 1st for Kano in 2015 (see ProMED-mail archive no. 20151227.3893839). As noted in the comments in ProMED-mail archive no. 20150228.3199551: "Lassa fever virus [LFV] is endemic in Nigeria, and multi-mammate mice (_Mastomys_ spp.) are the rodent hosts. Lassa fever is now a serious problem in 23 of the 36 states of that country."

LFV can be transmitted from person to person through contact with an infected individual's viremic blood in the absence of adequate personal protective equipment. Several cases of transmission have occurred in hospitals. Fortunately, there were no cases among the Kano AKTH staff in the previous ProMED-mail report.

As Mod.CP pointed out in his comment in archived posting 20130131.1524034: "In the countries of Africa, such as Nigeria, where Lassa fever is endemic, the disease is a significant cause of morbidity and mortality. While Lassa fever infection is normally mild or has no observable symptoms in about 80 per cent of people infected with the virus, the remaining 20 per cent have a severe, multisystem disease. Rarely, Lassa fever is associated with epidemics, during which the case-fatality rate can reach 50 per cent. There is no preventative vaccine or treatment. The antiviral drug ribavirin has been used with success in Lassa fever patients."

The virus is a member of the family _Arenaviridae_ and causes acute hemorrhagic fever. It is transmitted to humans from contact with food or household items contaminated with excreta of the reservoir rodent host. In the absence of adequate infection control measures, person-to-person virus transmission can occur in houses or in hospital environments, or in laboratories testing samples from patients.

Images of _Mastomys_ mice can be seen at http://www.ispot.org.za/node/255877.

Maps of Nigeria can be seen at http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/nigeria.pdf and
http://healthmap.org/promed/p/887. - Mod.TY]

See Also

2015
